Issues.Title: Nested slot become plain element
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.5.16

### Reproduction link
[https://jsfiddle.net/jfmorio/qp6ra20u/](https://jsfiddle.net/jfmorio/qp6ra20u/)

### Steps to reproduce
execute the JSFiddle

### What is expected?
the nested named slot will be recognized and rendered inside the <div class="named-slot-container"> in the end

### What is actually happening?
the nested named slot rendered as a plain element as default slot

---
Basically, slot needs to be defined at the root level. Maybe this is not possible with the current design.

A workaround is to define slot ONLY at the root level. https://jsfiddle.net/jfmorio/4pbno6je/

Issues.Title: Allow bitwise OR in template expressions with numbers
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.5.16

### Reproduction link
[https://jsfiddle.net/swLuey0f/](https://jsfiddle.net/swLuey0f/)

### Steps to reproduce
Pipes are used as bitwise OR operator. This was already noted here: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/issues/2422

I wanted to quickly round a number with `value | 0`. but I found that it didn't work. Only my knowledge of the rather unpopular filters feature in Vue helped me to realize why this does not work.

### What is expected?
My suggestion would be, to detect numbers for bitwise OR operations and strings for functions/filters. Since numbers can't be used for functions anyway. Or since filters are defined as properties within the `filters` object, we could at least scan if the filter exists.

> Vue.js actually supports the full power of JavaScript expressions inside all data bindings

This part of the documentation would be a lie otherwise. If you do not agree with the proposed change, I would at least document these exceptions there. But since the bitwise operator isn't that big in popularity, it may seem unconsiderable to bloat the documentation for this edge-case.

### What is actually happening?
bitwise operator does not get rendered

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Allow bitwise OR in template expressions with numbers" (#8304)

Issues.Title: The ref property is not registered properly in electron environment
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.5.16

### Reproduction link
[https://github.com/jjyyxx/vue-electron-repro.git](https://github.com/jjyyxx/vue-electron-repro.git)

### Steps to reproduce
Clone the electron project
Run:
```
npm i
npm start
```
The tooltip won't pop a popper on the right side.

Compare with the [jsfiddle](https://jsfiddle.net/rzn7vyfu/11/) with identical code.


### What is expected?
The tooltip should pop a popper on the right side in the electron app too.


### What is actually happening?
The tooltip didn't pop a popper on the right side in the electron app.


---
I investigated the issue, found that at `element-ui\packages\tooltip\src\main.js` Line 88 the render function passed `ref: 'popper'` into `createElement` function. The tooltip instance should get a ref to that VNode for the use in `element-ui\src\utils\vue-popper.js (a mixin)` Line 87. 

In a normal browser, setting a breakpoint at `vue.js` Line 5390 will see exactly one call with `vnode.data.ref` equals `popper` in 7 calls to the `registerRef` function, but in electron environment, setting a breakpoint at `vue.common.js` Line 5405 will never see such a call in 5 calls.

It seems that in electron environment, the ref is not registered properly.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "The ref property is not registered properly in electron environment" (#8300)

Issues.Title: Scoped slot always present in $scopedSlots even when v-if'd away
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.5.16

### Reproduction link
[https://jsfiddle.net/25bkaes1/](https://jsfiddle.net/25bkaes1/)

### Steps to reproduce
Note that the scoped slot has `v-if="false"` on it - it seems to me that it should never appear in `this.$scopedSlots`. Press the "run" button to trigger the initial render.

### What is expected?
The console should print "slot missing" and "default slot content" should appear in the rendered div.

### What is actually happening?
The console prints "slot present" and nothing appears in the rendered div. It seems like the `v-if` is being moved from the slot itself to the slot contents (which is why executing the slot returns nothing rather than "custom slot contents").

---
Consumers of my component may want to customize how a particular piece is being rendered. Using `v-if` to toggle this always results in the slot being defined in `this.$scopedSlots`. Based on [this commit](https://github.com/vuejs/vue/commit/68bdbf508b915872627676d6bf987bdac9e5fe97) it would seem that putting a `v-if` on a scoped slot is valid usage.

I could in theory check `this.$scopedSlots.content()` to see if they provided the slot, but this doesn't allow me to determine whether the user provided no slot, or they intentionally provided an empty slot.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Scoped slot always present in $scopedSlots even when v-if'd away" (#8305)

Issues.Title: Allow a user to read and write state on history entries
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?

Mobile apps that want to save scroll position for elements besides window.

This would also allow the user to save whatever they want to history state. A project I'm working on now needs to keep track of what's "focused" per page and this seems like the correct place for it. It could also be a nice place for temporary form data. I'm sure there's a lot of use cases outside of this.


### What does the proposed API look like?

I'm still thinking about it, though I think someone else thinking about it would be better. :)

I checked out `react-router` a bit and it looks like we can make state part of the Location object, so we can set it in `$router.push|replace({...})` or `next({...})` calls. They use an additional argument but we might not need to?

I took a quick look at react-router and it seems to allow for this: https://github.com/ReactTraining/react-router/blob/master/packages/react-router/docs/api/history.md

Also, this seems to talk directly to the situation we're facing with scrolling:
https://reacttraining.com/react-router/web/guides/scroll-restoration

Also some additional reading: https://github.com/ReactTraining/history#properties

Hopefully this is useful and doesn't seem like useless rambling.

Issues.Title: Function isObjectEqual (a, b) can return unexpected result if object a has properties with undefined values
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.0.1

### Reproduction link
[https://codepen.io/mburmistrov/pen/vrYWWR?editors=1112](https://codepen.io/mburmistrov/pen/vrYWWR?editors=1112)

### Steps to reproduce
Look at the codepen snippet.

It contains **isObjectEqual(a, b)** implementation from *vue-router/src/util/route.js* and an example of it's unexpected behaviour.

Console output represents the issue.

### What is expected?
In the codepen **isObjectEqual(a, b)** is used on two objects: 

```a: { foo: true, bar: undefined } ```

```b: { foo: true, baz: 'qux' } ```

What is expected: 
1. **isObjectEqual(a, b)** is expected to return false since **Object b** has 'baz' property with 'qux' value and **Object a**  doesn't have such property at all.

2. **isObjectEqual(b, a)** is expected to return false for the same reason.

3. **isObjectEqual(a, b)** result should be equal to **isObjectEqual (b, a)** result.

### What is actually happening?
What is happening:
1. **isObjectEqual(a, b)** returns true (unexpected).

2. **isObjectEqual(b, a)** returns false (expected).  

3. **isObjectEqual(a, b)** result is not equal to **isObjectEqual(b, a)** result  (unexpected).

Same thing will happen with any **Object a** and **Object b** if conditions below are met:

- **Object a** and **Object b** have the same amount of properties.

- **Object b** must have same properties with same values that are present in **Object a** with values different from undefined.


---
Issue with **isObjectEqual** causes issues with other functions that use it.

For example, **isSameRoute(a, b)** (from *vue-router/src/util/route.js*) can return true for routes with different query objects (if query objects meet conditions listed above).  

I ran into this bug because sometimes programmatic navigation worked in unexpected ways when using **router.push** with a query object.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Function isObjectEqual (a, b) can return unexpected result if object a has properties with undefined values" (#2233)

Issues.Title: store.registerGetters and store.registerActions
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
To be able to fully code split all application logic across application routes it would be helpful to have a way to dynamically register getters and actions.  Currently registerModule only supports registering namespaced modules with `store.registerModule`.  

For example lets say you have two namespaced modules that you dynamically load into your application: Sandwich and Human.  The two modules shouldn't know anything about each other.  There needs to be some highter level actions and getters that can tie the two together that you can also dynamically load.

### What does the proposed API look like?
```
store.registerActions({
  ...newActions
})

store.registerGetters({
  ...newGetters
})
```
These functions would still throw errors if the user tried to register duplicate actions or getters so it would be up the the user to make sure they are not passing in duplicates by checking existing data and making sure their actions and getters are namespaced appropriately.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "store.registerGetters and store.registerActions" (#1299)

Issues.Title: Option to namespace a module but not have it localized
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
The `namespaced:true` module feature has two main purposes: 

1. it automatically namespaces your modules API ( e.g store.getters['namespace/myGetter']). 
2. it localizes dispatch, commit, getters, and state. 

I'd like is to have an option when defining a module that does 1. but does not do 2. as mentioned above. I understand that there are currently two ways to achieve what I want in user land but neither of them are ideal.

1. Define modules that are `namespaced` that have actions and getters that only reference rootGetters, rootState and dispatch to root. I've never like using the root features. Seems like it throws encapsulation out of the door.
2. Define modules that are not `namespaced` and manually namespace modules yourself. This is currently what I'm doing.

### What does the proposed API look like?

String `namespace` - Setting `namespace` would namespace all actions, getters, and mutations with that value. A "." separator to be able to distinguish between a namespaced module that is localized ("/") and not localized ("."). A module with this setting should never have state as it's only purpose is to group together other modules actions, getters, and mutations to do higher order operations.

Some validations worth calling out.
- if the namespace option was set, validate that there is no state defined. 

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->

Issues.Title: Syntactic sugar for commiting mutations
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
Committing mutations has a very strange syntax, which really stands out negatively, compared to the otherwise very elegant APIs found in the Vue/Vuex ecosystem:

    this.$store.commit('someMutation', args...)

The docs mention that this is to emphasize that a commit is not a direct call to the mutation. I don't think this line of reasoning holds in the Vue/Vuex world. In almost all other aspects of Vue/Vuex, the API looks straight forward (e.g. just getting and setting properties), but under the hood a lot of additional logic runs (dependency tracking, etc.). So there is really no need to make committing mutations more cumbersome than they need to be.

In addition to making the code harder to read, this leads to additional rules about argument passing.

Moreover, it is very hard to spot typos in the mutation name early on, as the mutation name is just a string - let alone checking that the call to `commit()` received the correct arguments according to the mutation function. These types of errors should be easy to spot at compile time, but with the current syntax, these are all pushed into runtime.

Finally, this cumbersome syntax might be (correctly) perceived as boilerplate, especially to beginners. Hence, replacing the commit syntax with a more straight forward syntax might improve the adoption of Vuex.

### What does the proposed API look like?
Instead of:

    this.$store.commit('someMutation', args...)

one should be allowed to write:

    this.$store.someMutation(args...)

Moreover, it would be great if looking at `this.$store` in the developer console all available mutation methods are shown. That is, the methods should be real properties of this.$store, collected once at program start.

Under the hood, of course, these methods might all call some central commit() function.

Alternative syntax: The above syntax might introduce some name collisions. For example, someone might name one of their mutations "state", for whatever reason, making "this.$store.state" ambiguous. For the sake of simplicity, these names should just be forbidden as mutation names. But if this is not an option for whatever reason, an intermediate object might do the trick as well. This would be less beautiful, but still better than what we have today:

    this.$store.commit.someMutation(args...)

or shorter:

    this.$store.c.someMutation(args...)

As an additional proposal, the old `this.$store.commit()` syntax should be marked deprecated.  And removed in future Vuex versions. This generic call is not needed. Any generic commit call might as well be formulated as `this.$store[mutationName](args...)`, which is still easy to understand and even shorter than `this.$store.commit(mutationName, args...)`.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->

Issues.Title: The TypeScript definition files incorrectly specifies the map* functions as named exports.
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.0.1

### Reproduction link
[https://github.com/ciddan/vuex-ts-issue](https://github.com/ciddan/vuex-ts-issue)

### Steps to reproduce
Reproduction of an issue with the TypeScript type definitions in Vuex.

1. Clone the provided repository.
2. run npm install
3. run npm start
4. Open browser and go to http://localhost:8080.
5. Open dev tools and look at the console output.


### What is expected?
That the first log output: ```mapActions from: import { mapActions } undefined``` isn't undefined.

### What is actually happening?
mapActions is undefined.

---
Please read the README in the linked repository for full information on the issue.

We ran into this issue while working on TypeScript decorators that required the use of the various map functions.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "The TypeScript definition files incorrectly specifies the map* functions as named exports." (#1274)

Issues.Title: The TypeScript definition files incorrectly specifies the map* functions as named exports
Issues.Body:
This is incorrect:
https://github.com/vuejs/vuex/blob/4d573e9960f8cca33fdf9051521a203b03b18ae5/types/index.d.ts#L6

Looking at vuex.js and vuex.common.js all of these functions are exported in the default export, not as named exports. This breaks our TypeScript/SystemJS project - since the TypeScript type of the default export only contains Store and install. Importing the map functions as named exports, i.e:
``` typescript
import { mapActions } from "vuex";
```
doesn't work either - since they're undefined at run time (SystemJS handles default and named exports differently). 

With "system" as the module format defined in tsconfig.json usage of a a named export is compiled to:
``` javascript
vuex_1.mapActions
```
Whereas usage of a default export is compiled to:
``` javascript
vuex_1.default.Store
```

The map functions should be exported together with Store and install here:
https://github.com/vuejs/vuex/blob/4d573e9960f8cca33fdf9051521a203b03b18ae5/types/index.d.ts#L129-L132

For reference, this is the export from vuex.js:
https://github.com/vuejs/vuex/blob/4d573e9960f8cca33fdf9051521a203b03b18ae5/dist/vuex.js#L925-L936
